content.title: Atrial Fibrillation Rate Control
content.summary: Pharmacologic strategies for controlling ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation
key_points: Rate control is first-line for most AF patients
Lenient rate control (<110 bpm) is acceptable for most
Beta-blockers and non-DHP CCBs are first-line agents
Digoxin is second-line, useful in HFrEF
AV node ablation + pacemaker for refractory cases

statement.text: Rate control in atrial fibrillation aims to reduce ventricular rate to improve symptoms without attempting to restore sinus rhythm. First-line agents include beta-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers. Lenient rate control (resting HR <110 bpm) is non-inferior to strict control (<80 bpm) for most patients.
statement.formal: AF Rate Control = Beta-blocker OR Non-DHP CCB → Add digoxin if needed → Lenient target (<110) acceptable

explanation.intuition: In AF, the atria fire chaotically at 350-600/min, but the AV node filters these impulses. Rate control drugs slow AV conduction, reducing how many impulses reach the ventricles. A slower, more regular ventricular rate improves cardiac output and symptoms.
explanation.key_insight: The RACE II trial showed lenient rate control (<110 bpm at rest) is as safe as strict control (<80 bpm), with easier drug titration and fewer visits. Reserve strict control for persistent symptoms despite lenient control.

definitions_glossary.rate_control: Strategy to slow ventricular rate in AF without restoring sinus rhythm
definitions_glossary.strict_rate_control: Target resting HR <80 bpm and exercise HR <110 bpm
definitions_glossary.beta_blocker: Drugs blocking beta-adrenergic receptors, slowing AV conduction
definitions_glossary.non_DHP_CCB: Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (diltiazem, verapamil) - slow AV node
definitions_glossary.DHP_CCB: Dihydropyridine CCBs (amlodipine) - DON'T control rate (peripheral vasodilators)
definitions_glossary.digoxin: Cardiac glycoside enhancing vagal tone to slow AV conduction
definitions_glossary.AV_node_ablation: Catheter ablation of AV node + permanent pacemaker for refractory rate control
definitions_glossary.chronotropic_incompetence: Inability to appropriately increase HR with activity
definitions_glossary.tachycardia_induced_cardiomyopathy: HF from prolonged uncontrolled tachycardia; reversible with rate control
definitions_glossary.rapid_ventricular_response: RVR - ventricular rate >100 bpm in AF
definitions_glossary.congestive_symptoms: Dyspnea, edema from inadequate cardiac output in uncontrolled AF

pathophysiology.AV_node_conduction: AV node has intrinsic conduction slowing properties; rate-control agents enhance this

drug_mechanisms.beta_blockers: Block sympathetic stimulation of AV node → prolonged AV refractoriness
drug_mechanisms.non_DHP_CCBs: Block L-type calcium channels in AV node → slower conduction
drug_mechanisms.digoxin: Enhances vagal tone (parasympathetic) → decreased AV conduction; less effective with activity

beta_blockers.advantages: Good exercise rate control, beneficial in CAD and HFrEF
beta_blockers.cautions: Avoid in decompensated HF, severe asthma, bradycardia

non_DHP_CCBs.advantages: Good rate control, no beta-blocker side effects

digoxin.advantages: Useful in HFrEF, neutral effect on BP
digoxin.limitations: Less effective during exercise (sympathetic activation overrides vagal effect)
digoxin.monitoring: Serum digoxin level 0.5-1.0 ng/mL; watch for toxicity

amiodarone.role: Last resort for rate control when others fail or contraindicated

acute_rate_control.stable_patient: IV metoprolol 5mg q5min x3 or IV diltiazem 0.25mg/kg bolus → drip

AV_node_ablation.indication: Persistent symptoms despite maximal medical rate control
AV_node_ablation.procedure: Catheter ablation of AV node → pacemaker dependent
AV_node_ablation.outcome: Excellent rate control; pacemaker required for life

definition.@value: Pharmacologic and procedural strategies to control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation without restoring sinus rhythm

learning_objectives: Select appropriate first-line rate control agent based on comorbidities
Distinguish lenient vs strict rate control goals
Recognize when to avoid non-DHP CCBs (HFrEF)
Identify indications for AV node ablation
clinical_pearls: Non-DHP CCBs contraindicated in HFrEF - use beta-blockers + digoxin
Digoxin less effective during exercise - combine with beta-blocker if active patient
Lenient control (<110) is usually sufficient - don't over-titrate
Tachycardia-mediated cardiomyopathy is reversible with adequate rate control
NEVER use AV nodal blockers in WPW with AF (can trigger VF)
